citeinfo.title: COAL_DANVILLE_THICKNESS_NCRDS_IN_2011: Thickness Ranges of the Danville Coal Member (Dugger Formation, Pennsylvanian) in Southwestern Indiana (Indiana Geological Survey, 1:125,000, Polygon Shapefile)
citeinfo.othercit: This shapefile was compiled based on data from the National Coal Resource Data System Database (NCRDS_Indiana2011.mdb) (Indiana Geological Survey, Access Database). Mastalerz, M., and Drobniak, A., 2011, The Indiana Geological Survey Coal Stratigraphic Database: Indiana Geological Survey Report of Progress 39.

descript.abstract: In the past a series of reports on coal resources of selected counties in Indiana was published as part of the Special Report series of the Indiana Geological Survey. These reports included maps showing thickness of the Danville Coal Member (Dugger Formation, Pennsylvanian). The thickness maps were based on coal-test records, mine-map notations, and interpretations of geophysical logs that are included in the files of the Indiana Geological Survey. Different thickness ranges were used in the various counties and for different purposes. Since 1980, staff members of the Indiana Geological Survey (IGS) have also collected and entered coal resource information into the NCRDS database as a cooperative project with the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS). The purpose of NCRDS database is to provide a means of rapid retrieval of point-source coal resource information, including coal location, thickness, depth, and other parameters. Based on all available data as of October 2010, a new map of Danville Coal Member thickness was created. It is the most current thickness map of the Danville Coal Member. Because additional data on coal thicknesses are obtained by the Indiana Geological Survey on an annual basis, interested users may wish to contact the Indiana Geological Survey for information on these more up-to-date sources.
descript.purpose: COAL_DANVILLE_THICKNESS_NCRDS_IN_2011 was created to provide a multicounty digital shapefile, suitable for use in a GIS, from Indiana Geological Survey National Coal Resource Data System Database (NCRDS) a Microsoft Access database of public point-source coal-resource data in Indiana.

idinfo.native: ESRI ArcGIS version 10.0 polygon shapefile, Microsoft Windows 7.0, file size 3.26 Mb

attracc.attraccr: COAL_DANVILLE_THICKNESS_NCRDS_IN_2011 contains internal attributes with designations that refer to minimum and maximum values (in feet) of various thickness ranges. This shapefile was created using the NCRDS database, which contains information coming from several different sources including logs from coal-test drilling, interpretations of geophysical logs, and mine notations. The accuracy, precision, and distribution of these three types of data vary greatly. Mine-map notations are probably the most accurate, followed by drilling logs of good quality. Interpretations of geophysical logs are the least accurate source of information. The low resolution and the small scale of these logs make estimating coal thickness difficult. Because different types of data were used in the compilation of this shapefile, the user should assume that attribute values are no better than that achievable from the least accurate and precise source (namely interpretations of geophysical logs).

dataqual.logic: Visual inspection only; no quantitative tests were performed.
dataqual.complete: The digital shapefile was derived from the NCRDS database and is limited to extent of the Danville Coal Member in Indiana.

horizpa.horizpar: The accuracy of this ESRI ArcGIS shapefile is dependent upon the accuracy of the source data of each data point, and the accuracy with which these data were manually entered into the database.

procstep.procdesc: A Microsoft Access database named "NCRDS_Indiana2011.mdb," compiled as Indiana Geological Survey Report of Progress 39, was used to create this ESRI ArcGIS shapefile. 3,588 datapoints showing the thickness information of the Danville Coal Member were exported from the NCRDS database and using "Add X Y" command displayed in ArcMap. The "Export" command was then used to export the datapoints as a shapefile named "DAN_NCRDS_PT_2011.shp." Using Topo to Raster interpolation low-resolution thickness digital raster was created. The raster was reclasiffied into 1-foot ranges and exported as a COAL_DANVILLE_THICKNESS_NCRDS_IN_2011 shapefile. The shapefile was then smoothed using "smooth polygon" option in ArcToolbox.

This metadata was pre-parsed and parsed using CNS (Chew and Spit, v. 2.6.1) and MP (Metadata Parser, v. 2.7.1) software written by Peter N. Schweitzer (United States Geological Survey). The errors generated by MP were all addressed and corrected, except that no values were assigned to "Abscissa_Resolution" and "Ordinate_Resolution."
